segments.text: No problem, I'll just shut this off.
We're now recording.
Thank you for agreeing to see us today, Doctor.
I'm just curious, you mentioned when we came in that this is called a national library in name, but it is really not precisely that.
I wonder what you meant by that.
Yes, because a century ago they decided to give the title of national library to all the libraries of the
ancient independent Italian states.
So in Piedmont, in Turin, in Milan, in Venice.
So there are many national libraries, as many as the ancient states which existed before the Union.
Italy, there are two real national libraries, one in Florence and one in Rome.
So there are national libraries?
These are really national, in the sense that they have the right to have a copy of every book published in Italy.
So they're deposit libraries?
They're deposit libraries.
How about in terms of the collections?
Are they national ones that go beyond the deposit, I mean, like the special collections?
Well, the national libraries, this means in reality state libraries.
I see.
And they should have...

something of every subject but of course it's impossible in modern culture so we try to specialise ourselves a little so in our case we are determined by our history in the sense that we have a lot of precious things of classical culture and in particularly Greek so we go on buying books in the field of philology
Greek and Latin, and humanism, tradition of texts, those kind of things.
And also history, because we have many books concerning the Venetian history, and so we buy all about Venice, all the books related to the Venetian history.
And in general, history.
We don't find medicine, we don't find law.
Of course you find ancient books of law, but not modern.
So it would be impossible to cover the whole range of human knowledge.
So, roughly, what is the size of your holdings?
A little less than a million books.
So it's not much.
If you compare it with the Library of Congress, how many are they?
100 million, so... 117 million, they say.
117 million.
It's not all books.
And it's all of America.
It's not, you know, you have a number of, as you've already pointed out, your specialty here is Venice and Greece, and you have other libraries throughout Italy that have similar specialties.
Yes, a sort of division.
And that more or less represents the Italian character and nation, doesn't it?
I mean, the nation itself is only 120-something years old, so it's not...
That would explain to a great extent why there are so many different... Ah, yes, of course, yes.
The unity is very recent, yes.
When you say a million books, that's printed and manuscripts?
Yes, yes.
The manuscripts are 13,000, and we have 13,000 manuscripts.
For 24,000 editions of the 16th century, Cinque Centine, 2,400
44, 46 Incunabula, and not much else.
If we could talk a little bit, we're very interested in the role of Venice and the fall of Constantinople and the migration of Greek texts and culture here.
This is a very, this library is a repository for a lot of that material, isn't it?
Yes, of course, yes, yes.
No, because we are born from the donation of Bessarion, who was a Greek, as you know.
It is to say that we started, the first idea of a public, of a library belonging to the state and open to the public in Venice was conceived by Petrarch.
Petrarcha.
That's a long time ago.
Long time ago, in 1360.
It was near to do it in 1362.
He proposed to the Venetian Republic a sort of agreement.
He said, I give you my library.
He had the most important library in Europe at the time.
After my death it will become property of the Venetian state.
But even now it would be open to the scholars and so on.
In exchange, you give me a house where I could live for my life.
So the Venetian state accepted.
There was a solemn proto.
This is from inside, so I cannot stop them.
I should make a circular... This is your work, and you're very kind to take the time from this.
Coming back to Petrarch, there was a solemn deliberation on the Great Council of Venice in September 1362, and
Petrarch came to Italy, to Venice.
He stayed here on the river degli Schiavoni for five years.
The house is no longer there, unfortunately.
But the place is, there is another building.
But then he changed his mind.
He went to Padova, carrying his life with him, and he left.

because he was not happy at the beginning, yes, but after the Doge, Chelsea, who was a friend of him, died, the great Chancellor Benintendi, who was another friend of him, died, the new Doge, Marco Corner, was not particularly interested, but mainly the fact was that he hoped to have more success, more followers,
But Venice was not yet prepared to this kind of vision of the world with humanistic.
They were more aristotelic, more interested in science, in medicine.
Petrarch hated the physicians.
So they couldn't... He preferred to go to Padua where the Signore was his friend.
And he stayed back there.
And so this project was not carried on.
It was not definitive.
The person who gave birth to the library was Cardinal Bessarian, who was an extraordinary figure of the humanistic world.
He was born in Trebizond at the beginning of the century.
Which century?
Potrocento, 15th century.
And he was born in Trebizond.
The date is not sure about the beginning of the century.
Then he went to Constantinople, he studied there with scholars.
He was still a great center of culture.
Then he became a monk, a Brazilian monk.
passed some years in Mistra, where there was a great scholar called Gemistos, Plato.
George Gemistos.
I don't know how he was in Greek.
Gemistos, I think.
It's Plato?
Plato.
So not Plato.
Plato.
P-L-A-T-H.
Because he was a sort of surname, because he was a follower of Plato, the ancient.
And so he tried to, gemistos means full.
So he'd take a name with Plato, sort of translation of his name, and also reminded the name of Plato.
And so he's a great, an eccentric and extraordinary figure, a great, great scholar, and he was a pagan.
He was not a believer in any religion.
He was a follower of real ancient philosophy.
And Bessarion stayed there for some years, and he became familiar with the culture of ancient Greece.
He knew very well astronomy, all sciences, and also the classical literature.
Then he became Archbishop.
He came to Italy in 1438.
in order to participate to the council, the ecumenical council of Ferrara, Firenze, because they wanted to try to unite the two churches, the Greek and the Latin.
So he came here and he passed through Venice going to Ferrara and in this moment started a great friendship with many figures of the Venetian aristocracy and clergy.
And then he went to Ferrara to Florence.
He was the leader of the group who was in favor of the Union.
So he became the most important figure in this group of Greek.
And there were many bishops, archbishops and monks and so on.
Plato, Plato,

And then the Union was proclaimed in Florence, and the Stalinists were very happy, but unfortunately the Greeks did not accept it, because they found it probably, it has risen probably, they found it was a sort of trick made by the West in order to limit the liberty of the East.
The Emperor wanted it very strongly because he wanted to have allies against the Turks that were surrounding the city.
But the Greeks just said that this was not a solution.
And so, Vestalian remained in Rome.
He went back to Constantinople, seeing the atmosphere against the Union.
He preferred to come back to Rome.
He became a cardinal.
And then he devoted his life to
do all what he could to help his countrymen in Greece, organizing leagues against the Turks and so on, but with no success because of course he fell and so on.
But what he did in fact was to transform his private library into the Greek national library in some sense.
He wanted to buy or to have copied
for what he could find of the Greek ancient culture.
Not particularly the religious books, because there were many, but books which were in danger to be destroyed were the classical books, the ancient books.
And so he created a very important library, about a thousand books for the Epochism Arch, let's say six
600 Greeks and the remaining Latin.
And then, at the end of his life, he decided to give it to Venice because he thought it was the most proper place where these books would be kept, would be preserved.
And also there were many Greeks who came to Venice.
It was in Padova, the center of Greek culture.
Many friends of him had great positions in the government.
So he found that the
best place where to put his treasury was Venice.
And also there was a reason that Venice was the only European power who was effectively fighting against the Turks.
And he came here the first time in 1438.
Then he came back probably another time
Then he stayed for more than one year in 1463-64.
And then he made his donation in 1468.
The books arrived a year later, but he kept some books for himself because he was still active in culture and politics and so on.
And the remaining part right when he died in 72.

Was it named after him?
No, he gave it to Venice, to the Venetian state, to St.

it was in fact a donation to Venice to the Venetian public and in exchange Venice accepted the gift and promised to build a proper space for the library and this required a long time because they started only in 1527 and before the books were kept in the Ducal Palace in a room over here and

the Carraresi, the family of Carraresi.

Petrarca Boccaccio wrote in Florentine.

and the Planudean anthology, which is ours, made by a monk called Planudes in the year 1300.
